awd_titl_txt: Reversible Metal Electrodeposition for Modulating Light
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Reversible Metal Electrodeposition for Modulating Light


The project team is developing windows whose tinting can be adjusted by applying a voltage between two transparent electrodes to either electroplate metal or remove the metal. These windows could reduce heating, cooling and lighting costs in buildings by 20% and allow people to enjoy the views through their windows even when the window is partially tinted to control glare.  This technology is expected to enable people to have better moods and be more productive by optimizing the amount of natural daylight they have. The project team is distributing kits to high school teachers and helping them show students how to make the windows. Through the construction of these dynamic windows, high school students are learning valuable concepts in electrochemistry, optics and architectural engineering with a project that is easy to visualize and has a clear purpose.  

The adoption of high-performing dynamic windows based on reversible metal electrodeposition will increase the energy efficiency and comfort of buildings. Dynamic windows in buildings result in an average of 20% energy savings and 2% increase in workplace productivity due to improved management of lighting and temperature. The large extinction coefficients and intrinsic robustness of metals make them ideal materials for dynamic thin films. Compared to traditional materials such as electrochromics, reversible metal electrodeposition is an underexplored strategy for constructing switchable thin films. Over the last five years, the McGehee and Barile groups have designed new strategies that enable enhanced control over reversible metal electrodeposition on transparent electrodes. The underlying objective of this research is to determine the physical and chemical parameters that yield rapid and reversible metal electrodeposition on transparent conducting electrodes with tailored optical properties and outstanding durability for optoelectronically switchable thin films. This work is applicable to energy-saving dynamic windows for buildings and automobiles, switchable eyewear, and cameras. The project team’s unique research strategies are enabling the development of dynamic thin films with an unprecedented control over device optical contrast, switching speed, scalability, and cycle life. The work is aiding the progress of metal-based switchable films through the development of alkaline and Zn electrolytes with enhanced voltage stabilities, polymer-modified electrodes that allow for uniform tinting on a large scale, pulsed electrodeposition techniques to control device optics, and systematic durability studies that are enhancing the cycle lives of the devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Dynamic windows based on reversible metal electrodeposition (RME) electronically tint and bleach, enabling user control of light into and out of buildings. The widespread adoption of electronically adjustable dynamic windows could significantly improve the energy efficiency of buildings.  The operating mechanism is to reversibly electrodeposit a thin layer of metal (e.g. Cu and Bi) onto a transparent conductor to block light.  Tinting to a desired opacity is constrained by a rough film morphology using direct current (DC) electrodeposition, limiting window switching speed. We showed that smoother films can be grown with pulsed electrodeposition with a 10% duty cycle and 1 Hz frequency because ions are able to diffuse past protrusions during the rest phase. While these films initially tint slower compared to DC plating, the films using this pulsing protocol reach 0.1% transmittance 45 % faster. We demonstrate an optimized tinting protocol that consists of 10 s of DC plating then pulsing that achieves the 0.1% transmittance in 58% less time than DC only plating. Finally, we showed that pulsing enables consistent optical properties of dynamic windows after 2,400 cycles due to effective suppression of dendrite growth on the metal mesh counter electrode.

We developed robust dynamic windows based on the reversible metal electrodeposition (RME) of Zn from DMSO electrolytes. We systematically interrogated the role of anions, cations, and polymer additives on electrolyte properties and developed design rules to increase the electrochemical and optical reversibility of these systems. This fundamental understanding allowed us to develop an electrolyte that facilitates reversible Zn electrodeposition with unprecedented speed and reversibility with a Coulombic efficiency of 99.5%. We implemented this electrolyte into practical two-electrode 25 cm2 dynamic windows and demonstrated that these devices switch more than 11,000 times without degradation in optical performance and without altering the switching speed or voltage profile. This outstanding durability is unprecedented in the field of RME windows and brings metal-based dynamic windows substantially closer to successful commercialization.

Ag is an attractive metal for RME windows because only one electron is needed to reduce its cation, and it has a high intrinsic extinction coefficient. However, reversible Ag electrodeposition devices with better than 24 h resting stability and cyclability over 1000 cycles have not been reported simultaneously. We develop Ag-dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) electrolytes that support reversible electrodeposition with high optical contrast (~75% clear-state transmission and <0.1% dark-state transmission). Cu is often used to promote cyclability in RME windows. However, Cu2+ causes the Ag films to dissolve in 30 min when the window is in the dark state. In addition to Cu2+, O2 can chemically dissolve Ag films in the presence of Br-. In the absence of Cu, Ag windows suffer from Ag2O or AgOH formation and cannot cycle more than 100 times before appearing white. We introduce trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) into the electrolyte to prevent Ag2O and AgOH formation, enabling consistent optical properties over 7500 cycles. Without Cu and by eliminating dissolved O2, we demonstrate that Ag films can stay at <0.1% dark-state transmission for more than 80 days.

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2025
Modified by: Michael D Mcgehee
